I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Solar energy has been regarded as one of the fastest growing electricity technologies in 
recent  years.  Changes  in  technology,  cost  structure,  enabling  policies,  and  regulatory 
frameworks have driven this spectacular growth in developed countries. Solar energy has great 
significance  for  developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific  because  
(i)  economies  of  scale  can  reduce  costs  to  make  solar  energy  competitive  with  the  grid;  
(ii) some DMCs have greater solar radiation, more rapidly growing electricity demand, and more 
availability of land than developed countries; and, as a result, (iii) DMCs have the potential to 
become global and regional technology manufacturing hubs for solar technology goods and 
equipment.  
 
2.  Strategy 20201 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) outlines the following priorities:  
(i) realizing environmentally sustainable growth for Asia and the Pacific; (ii) expanding ADB's 
promotion  of,  and  investment  in,  sound  environmental  management,  while  simultaneously 
capitalizing on ADB's operational strengths, such as infrastructure development and finance; 
and (iii) responding to climate change and supporting DMCs to move their economies onto  
low-carbon growth paths by expanding the use of clean energy. ADB's 2009 Energy Policy2 was 
designed  to  increase  its  role  in  renewable  energy  development  by  (i)  facilitating  wider 
technology deployment, (ii) raising awareness and promoting policy and regulatory incentives to 
encourage use of renewable energy, and (iii) promoting financing packages that share risks and 
lower costs. The Energy Policy includes maximizing access to energy for all as one of its three 
pillars. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  While ADB has begun to process several solar energy and stable grid development3  
projects in line with the Energy Policy, the ADB solar technology team established under the 
energy community of practice in September 2009 has identified several barriers to such projects. 
These  include:  (i)  insufficient  concessional  and  secured  financing  mechanisms,  (ii)  slow 
technology transfer to DMCs, (iii) suboptimal capacity of DMCs to develop and implement 
sustainable policy and regulatory frameworks, and (iv) weak industry structures for solar energy 
and stable grid development.  
 
4.  At an international workshop as the side event of the Copenhagen climate summit in 
December 2009, R. K. Pachauri, the chair of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, 
presented a number of proposals to support ADB's work with DMCs to mainstream solar energy 
development: 
 
(i)  the  private  sector  should  play  a  major  role  in  combating  climate  change, 
especially in solar energy development;  
(ii)  developing  countries  should  have  a  policy  for  mainstreaming  solar  energy 
development  with  active  private  sector  participation  (e.g.,  the  National  Solar 
Mission of India's National Action Plan on Climate Change);

(iii)  all  stakeholders—developing  and  developed  country  agencies,  international 
agencies, the private sector, and nonprofit organizations—should have extensive 
dialogue to identify issues, share perceptions and find  solutions; and 
(iv)  ADB should play a facilitation role by setting up a network for knowledge sharing.  
 
5.  Strategy 2020 calls for knowledge solutions that will leverage ADB’s central position in 
identifying trends within and across the region, its interdisciplinary and integrated assistance 
approach,  and  its  capacity  to  implement  insight  and  knowledge  supported  by  significant 
financing. ADB, together with its development partners, is therefore in a position to play a 
catalytic role in technology transfer facilitation and knowledge sharing for solar energy and 
stable grid development. As a regional knowledge institution, ADB is mandated to (i) support 
pilot projects from which it will distill and disseminate lessons, and (ii) distribute knowledge in 
ways that have both an immediate impact and catalytic force. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
6.  This regional capacity development technical assistance (TA) aims to promote solar 
energy and stable grid development in Asia and the Pacific. The TA will contribute to an 
understanding by all stakeholders of the potential for solar energy in the region, the key actions 
required to accelerate solar energy development, the institutional and business models for 
development  and  deployment,  and  the  mechanisms  to  promote  technology  transfer  to 
developing countries and to enhance the scope for cooperation on research and development 
(R&D).  
 
7.  This initiative will cover (i) large scale solar photovoltaic (SPV) and solar thermal projects, 
(ii) grid-connected distributed SPV projects, (iii) off-grid solar power generation projects, (iv) 
stable  grid  development  projects  using  batteries  and  two-way  meters,  and  (v)  associated 
technologies, e.g., lithium-ion batteries, plug-in electric vehicles.4 In order to mainstream such 
projects, a well-organized and systematic knowledge management program will be critical and 
will need to involve (i) DMC governments, (ii) private sector and R&D agencies, and (ii) donor 
countries and development partners.  
 
8.  Through  the  knowledge  management  program,  DMC  governments  will  be  able  to 
(i) promote foreign direct investment by international private companies; (ii) facilitate technology 
transfer by matching domestic and foreign private companies, e.g., manufacturers, developers, 
suppliers, and financiers; (iii) mobilize concessional funding from development partners and 
developed countries to structure financially viable projects; (iv) formulate and implement an 
optimal solar policy and regulatory framework so that many private sector enterprises can enter 
the  market;  and  (v)  receive  capacity  development  support  from  developed  countries  and 
development partners. 
 
9.  The private sector will be able to: (i) have access to DMC government policy makers,  
(ii) acquire the latest information on DMC market development, (iii) develop consortia with 
foreign  and  domestic  enterprises,  and  (iv)  approach  development  partners  and  developed 
country governments to provide financial and technical assistance with which the bankable 
projects can be developed. The knowledge management program will also be beneficial for 
ADB and its development partners as they will be able to (i) promote regional and national 
policy dialogue, (ii) tailor lending and guarantee operations to DMCs and the private sector,  
(iii) develop effective technical assistance to match the needs of DMCs and the private sector,

operation is in Appendix 2. 
   
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The expected impact of the TA is sustainable solar energy and stable grid development 
in Asia and the Pacific for inclusive and low-carbon economic growth. The expected outcome is 
needs assessment and pilot programs conducted for knowledge management to promote solar 
energy and stable grid development in Asia and the Pacific. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The TA will conduct a comprehensive needs assessment for a knowledge platform and 
pilot programs for solar energy and stable grid management in Asia and the Pacific.  
 
12.  The  impact  of  the  knowledge  management  platform  will  be  maximized  by  (i)  the 
participation of a large number of stakeholders, among others, from Europe and North America  
where  commercial  solar  power  generation  projects  are  already  being  actively  developed;  
(ii) regular international workshops and capacity development programs in the region, with 
collaboration from other development partners; and (iii) the establishment of an institutional 
knowledge  network  connecting  the  region  to  the  rest  of  the  world,  adding  value  through 
investment,  optimizing  implementation  arrangements,  achieving  economies  of  scale,  and 
developing unified approaches.  
 
13.  The outputs for the proposed TA are as follows. 
 
(i)  A prefeasibility study5 of the knowledge management platform will be conducted. 
As  an  initial  step,  a  consultant  will  identify  the  key  areas  where  knowledge 
management can effectively facilitate solar energy and stable grid development 
in DMCs in Asia and Pacific. The consultant will identify barriers and solutions in 
the  areas  of  (a)  technology  transfer,  (b)  innovative  financing,  (c)  policy  and 
regulatory frameworks, and (d) industries and market structures in DMCs. The 
consultant will analyze the current knowledge management activities conducted 
by  global,  regional,  and  national  agencies,  nonprofit  organizations,  and 
institutions and  identify  quantitative  and  qualitative  gaps  between  knowledge 
supply and demand. The consultant will deliver a prefeasibility report on an 
independent,  not-for-profit,  nonpartisan,  and  nonpolitical  knowledge  platform 
involving ADB, its development partners, knowledge and financial providers, and 
DMC governments and private agencies.  
 
(ii)  An international solar energy forum will be held with relevant partners, e.g., 
International  Energy  Agency,  Renewable  Energy  and  Energy  Efficiency 
Partnership,  and  United  Nations  Industry  Development  Organization. 
Stakeholders will be invited to brainstorm and recommend specific measures to 
overcome barriers to viable SPV, solar thermal, and distributed rooftop solar 
power projects and sustainable off-grid and mini-grid projects using batteries. 
The  forum  is  scheduled  for  July  2010  in  Bangkok,  Thailand.  It  will  give  an

opportunity (a) for DMCs to attract foreign direct investments; (b) for private 
companies from DMCs to meet foreign technology partners; (c) for international 
private companies to learn about policies and incentive packages; and (d) for 
donor agencies to structure client oriented assistance. 
 
(iii)  A pilot regional capacity development and knowledge sharing program will be 
conducted to strengthen the capacity of DMCs to formulate and implement policy 
and  regulatory  frameworks  for  mainstreaming  solar  energy  and  stable  grid 
development.  The  program  will  be  hosted  by  the  Government  of  Japan  in 
September 2010. Regional and nonregional private companies and agencies will 
be invited to disseminate best practices. Several agencies in Japan will share the 
costs of the program.  
 
(iv)  A consultant will assist ADB to develop agreements with international agencies 
and  companies  to  collaborate  in  project  development  and  knowledge 
management for solar energy and stable grid development. The target agencies 
will  include  international  organizations,  donor  agencies,  private  sector 
associations, and R&D institutes. In parallel, the consultant will promote South–
South cooperation. For example, the consultant will support knowledge providers 
in DMCs that have fairly well advanced policy development to share their best 
practices with other DMCs.  
 
(v)  A  consultant  will  develop  and  conduct  an  outreach  program  to  disseminate 
information on activities in DMCs and on ADB's expanding operations in project 
development  and  knowledge  management  in  solar  energy  and  stable  grid 
development.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,000,000 equivalent on a grant basis funded by 
the Asian Clean Energy Fund6 under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility, and 
administered by ADB. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will be the executing agency for this TA. The solar technology team under the 
energy community of practice will supervise the work of the consultants in close coordination 
with the Regional and Sustainable Development Department and other operational departments.  
 
16.  The TA will require the services of three international consultants for 19 person-months 
and  two  national  consultants  for  8  person-months,  for  a  total  of  27  person-months.  The 
international consulting team will include an international solar energy knowledge management 
specialist, an international solar business development specialist, an international renewable 
outreach  specialist,  a  national  logistics  coordinator,  and  a  national  training  specialist.  The 
consultants will be separately recruited as individuals as flexibility is needed in sourcing a broad 
range of specialists. ADB will recruit the consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be 
made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.7

17.  The consultants will coordinate with consultants working on other TA projects including 
capacity development TA (for e.g. TA 7473 REG: Solar Energy Development in South Asia) and 
PPTA for development of solar projects. The consultants’ terms of reference are in Appendix 4. 
Activities funded by this TA will start in a DMC only after ADB has received a written statement 
of no-objection from the government. The TA is expected to be implemented over 12 months 
from April 2010 to March 2011.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 to be financed on 
a grant basis by the Asian Clean Energy Fund under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership 
Facility for Needs Assessment and Development of the Solar Energy Program, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS  
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require the services of five international consultants.  
 
B.  Scope of Work 
 
2.  The TA is expected to be implemented over 12 months from April 2010 to March 2011. 
However, the work should be concentrated within the first 3 months. The professional positions 
and activities for the required positions are as follows. 
 
1.  Solar  Energy  Knowledge  Management  Specialist  (international, 9 person-
months) 
3.  The consultant will deliver a prefeasibility study report on the concept and design of a 
new knowledge platform for solar-energy-based power generation and stable grid development 
in the Asia and Pacific developing member countries (DMCs). The consultant should have 
extensive knowledge and experience to lead international knowledge management projects for 
solar energy development, especially, for large scale SPV projects with engineering skill on 
solar and network management capacity. The prefeasibility report will be developed through the 
following steps.  
 
(i)  Analyze  and  review  other  agencies'  international  cooperation  initiatives  for 
knowledge management and studies on realistic, practical, and demonstrative 
approaches to achieve utility-scale solar photovoltaic (SPV) power generation 
projects. This analysis will include past results and current efforts of international 
organizations, e.g., implementing strategies and engineering designs for large- 
scale solar projects. The same analysis will be conducted for (a) large-scale solar 
thermal,  (b)  distributed  grid-connected  roof-top  SPV,  (c)  off-grid  SPV,  and  
(d) stable grid development.   
(ii)  Examine the barriers for developing large scale SPV projects in Asia and Pacific 
DMCs in terms of technical, financial, and regulatory aspects.  
(iii)  Conduct knowledge mapping and gap analysis for solar energy and stable grid 
development.  
(iv)  Based  on  the  outcomes  of  the  above,  provide  a  prefeasibility  study  report, 
including institutional and logistical aspects and a road map for developing an 
independent,  not-for-profit,  non-partisan,  non-political  knowledge  platform 
involving  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  its  partners,  knowledge  and 
financial providers, and DMC governments and private agencies to (a) add value 
to  the  ongoing  work  of  organizations  and  initiatives  in  terms  of  investment, 
optimizing  implementation  arrangements,  achieving  economies  of  scale,  and 
developing  unified  approaches  to  solar  energy  policies  and  programs;  and  
(b)  encourage  more  collaborative  efforts  on  solar  energy  and  stable  grid 
development. 
 
4.   The consultant will prepare, organize, and conduct a solar energy forum in the form of  
an international workshop in Thailand. The consultant should have extensive knowledge and 
experience of power generation, transmission, and distribution. The activities of the consultant 
will include:

Appendix 4       11 
 
(i)  Develop the detailed agenda and schedule, manage invitation, organize each 
session, and develop website for the registration of the international workshop to 
be held in July 2010. 
(ii)  Prepare an issues paper to be the basis for brainstorming and recommending 
specific  measures  to  overcome  barriers  to  viable  SPV,  solar  thermal  and 
distributed rooftop solar power projects and sustainable off-grid and mini-grid 
projects using batteries which could be used for electric vehicles.  
(iii)  Engage  experts  and  development  practitioners  as  participants  and  prepare 
technical papers and presentations related to the themes of the forum.  
(iv)  Nominate the participants from the stakeholders and facilitate invitations. 
(v)  Work with national logistic coordinator and national training specialist for the 
forum.   
(vi)  Prepare a flyer and other publications for the forum.  
(vii)  Facilitate the workshop in terms of logistics, documentation, secretariat services, 
dissemination of information and materials, and related support.  
(viii)  Prepare the report of the outcome of the workshop.  
 
5.  The  consultant  will  also  prepare,  organize  and  conduct  a  pilot  regional  capacity 
development and knowledge sharing program in Japan to be hosted by the Government of 
Japan for solar energy and stable grid development in DMCs in Asia and the Pacific. The 
activities will include: 
 
(i)  Develop  a detailed agenda and schedule for two pilot capacity development and 
knowledge  sharing  programs  in  close  consultation  with  ADB  and  the 
stakeholders. 
(ii)  Engage distinguished experts and development practitioners as participants and 
to prepare technical papers and presentations related to the themes of the forum. 
(iii)  Nominate the participants from stakeholders and facilitate invitations. 
(iv)  Prepare a flyer and other publications for the program. 
(v)  Facilitate the program in terms of logistics, documentation, secretariat services, 
dissemination of information and materials, and related support.  
 
2.  Solar Business Development Specialist (international, 5 person-months) 
6.   The consultant will assist ADB to formulate memoranda of understanding (MOUs) with 
50 relevant agencies with global reach which can collaborate and cooperate with ADB to 
expand operation and knowledge management in solar energy and stable grid development. 
These agencies will be mainly in Europe and North America and will have expertise in policy, 
finance, and technology for commercial solar energy project development. The activities of this 
position include: 
 
(i)  Conduct  consultations  in  person  or  through  video-  or  teleconferences  with 
stakeholders, e.g.,  (a) governments, developers, manufacturers, financiers, and 
research and development (R&D) agencies, nonprofit organizations, media in 
DMCs in Asia and the Pacific; (b) developed member country governments;  
(c)  international  agencies,  e.g.,  United  Nations  organizations,  International 
Renewable  Energy  Agency,  International  Energy  Agency,  bilateral  donor 
agencies, nonprofit organizations, developers, financiers, R&D institutes, private 
sector associations, media in Europe, North America, and Asia and the Pacific;

and (d) 10 global leading manufacturers of SPV, solar thermal, smart grid, and 
batteries. Report on these consultations.  
(ii)  Identify interest among private companies in Europe, North America, Asia and 
the Pacific to enter the solar energy and stable grid development market in 
DMCs in Asia and the Pacific.  
(iii)  Consult with government agencies of developed member countries in Europe, 
North America, and Asia and the Pacific and identify how they expect ADB to 
play a role of promoting private sector participation in this area. 
(iv)  Draft an MOU between ADB and each stakeholder to promote solar energy and 
stable grid development projects in Asia and the Pacific region. 
(v)  Facilitate formulation of 50 MOUs between ADB and stakeholder agencies. 
 
3.  Renewable Energy Outreach Specialist (international, 5 person-months) 
7.   The consultant will develop and conduct an outreach program covering ADB's projects 
and knowledge management for solar energy and stable grid development in close collaboration 
with the relevant ADB departments and offices. The activities will include: 
 
(i)  Draft 3-year outreach action plan to (a) promote ADB's operations in project 
development  and  knowledge  management  for  solar  energy  and  stable  grid 
development, and (b) provide information on the initiatives and efforts of DMCs in 
Asia and the Pacific DMCs in this area.  
(ii)  Conduct  consultations  in  person  or  through  video-  or  teleconferences  with 
stakeholders, e.g., (a) media; (b) selected local communities; (c) governments, 
developers,  manufacturers,  financiers,  and  R&D  agencies,  nonprofit

governments;  (e)  international  agencies,  e.g.,  United  Nations  organizations, 
International Renewable Energy Agency, International Energy Agency, bilateral 
donor agencies, nonprofit organizations, developers, financiers, R&D institutes, 
private sector associations, media in Europe, North America, and Asia and the 
Pacific; and (f) 10 global leading enterprises in manufacturing SPV, solar thermal, 
smart grid, and batteries respectively. The summary of the consultation will be 
reported.  
(iii)  Implement  the  first  phase  of  the  action  plan  in  close  collaboration  with  the 
relevant ADB departments and offices.  
 
4.  Logistics Coordinator (national, 4 person-months) 
8.   The activities of the coordinator include: 
(i)  Support the international consultants to facilitate meetings, including logistical 
elements, documentation, secretariat services, dissemination of information and 
materials, and related support. 
(ii)  Reimburse selected participants for travel, hotel and per diem, and incidental 
expenses.  
(iii)  Conduct financing arrangement for the preparation of technical papers and post-
forum and program publications.

Appendix 4       13 
5.  National Training Specialist (national, 4 person-months) 
9.   The consultant will work under the direction of Solar Energy Knowledge Management 
Specialist. The activities of this specialist include:  
(i)  Support the international consultants to facilitate a training program, including 
logistical  aspects,  documentation,  secretariat  services,  dissemination  of 
information and materials, and related support. 
(ii)  Reimburse selected participants for travel, hotel and per diem, and incidental 
expenses.  
(iii)  Conduct financing arrangements for the preparation of training program. 
(iv)  Assist the team leader to conduct follow-up activities, including publication and 
posting on the ADB website. 
 
C.  Reporting Requirements 
10.   The consultant will work under the direction of Solar Energy Knowledge Management 
Specialist. The following reports will be produced for each assignment at key stages of the TA 
implementation: 
(i)  an inception report within 1 calendar month of TA commencement,  
(ii)  a midterm report within 2 calendar months of TA commencement, 
(iii)  a draft final report within 9 calendar months of TA commencement, and 
(iv)  a final report at the end of the 11th calendar month following TA commencement, 
following incorporation of all the comments received. 
 
11.   Each consultant will submit five copies of each report, and three digital copies of the final 
version of each report on CD-ROM to ADB in English.
